data.text: Zenith Solar Backpack when Cycle Touring?

Sorry if this has been discussed many times already.... I'm hesitating about getting a solar panel in addition to my powerbank. And just came across a pedestrian today with a solar panel integrated into his backpack!!! The idea is brilliant - do any of you use this kind of gadget? This is the one I saw on the street (Voltaic), but of course there are also many others brand with different options.... Any tips? https://voltaicsystems.com/offgrid/ https://sunslice-solar.com/products/zenith?variant=39436795773011
Zenith - Solar Backpack

The Zenith Solar Backpack Stay charged up anywhere, all the time, without even thinking about it. The Sunslice Zenith is a lightweight, practical and stunning solar backpack designed to give you combined functionnalities of a good daily-use modernist backpack and a powerful solar charger. It is perf...

Why is 'touring' more about electronics than travel? FWIW Size matters, smaller it is the longer the charge time & less power...

data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: most traveler , have some sort of electronic NAV equipment , a internet access , cell phone of small laptop . Also need light for your camp , all of the above needs charging . A cell phone for emergency is the very Min with regard to electronics , it needs to be charged . Either large power bank or a small solar panel .

data.text: why are you telling me this? Iâ€™m the one telling Robert Clark that having electronics is normal and nothing to be ashamed of.

data.text: sorry address the wrong person
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: The added weight on your body, decrease in ventilation (reduced evapotranspiration, increased heat + fatigue), and potential for increased friction to cause skin irritation make backpacks suboptimal for touring, regardless of their secondary purpose.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: no says the backpack has to be on you back , can be strapped to the top of rear carrier and charge bank as you cycle
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: but yes agree don't want it on you back
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: Iâ€™ve had two solar bags in the past (6 and 3 years ago), and as far as I could tell they never added any charge to the power banks I carried. Thatâ€™s really saying something, since the second bag I used while bike touring in India, and the panel was in the hot Indian sun for at least six hours a day. Then again, we see dramatic improvements in solar panels each year, so maybe the bags with solar panels are a lot more efficient these days.
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: I wouldn't vouch for a system which has it all. Let me explain, solar power banks tend to fail when batteries fail. They have poor temperature management and are expensive to replace. I have solar charger i use successfully, with an independent 20Ah Anker bank. That worked really well for me, with a 14w foldable panel. It kept my single power bank full through European peak of summer for a week.
data.author: Sanran Gulsen

data.text: thanks for your reply!! Can you give me the brand/model of your charger and powerbank?
data.author: Julia Mir

data.text: i have 20 Ah Anker for the bank. Solar is a random cheap brand. I guess Anker does them too and its a good brand that does things to last. The key is to never charge phone from panel directly because screen goes on and off with shades, draining more power. And also keep battery buried in panniers rather than right underneath panel to avoid heating.
data.author: Sanran Gulsen

data.text: My folding solar charger has a pocket holding a 10kmah power bank, & they travel together whether in my suitcase or hanging over a pannier.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: thanks for your reply!! Can you give me the brand/model of your charger and powerbank?
data.author: Julia Mir

data.text: How come all product recommendations come from profiles that are empty
data.author: John Axson

data.text: Indeed my profile is empty, but this is because I never post anything about myself on Facebook. I only use it as a forum - or rather multiple forums - unfortunately most forums I've been member of have been dying or losing most of their members and people moved to other forms of online communications, such as Facebook groups. Don't take me wrong: this is NOT a product recommendation. Just an open question with 2 links to the kind of products I've been thinking about. However I'm now convinced that this 3 in 1 gadget is not the best value for money ratio - at least not for a bike trip. Separate panels and powerbanks seem to be wiser purchases.
data.author: Julia Mir

data.text: You are right to be hesitant. You need the solar panel to be in optimal position at the optimal time of day to realize any gains from it. Best bet are thin flexible panel(s) on top of your pannier rack or trailer facing the sun.
data.author: Chris McCall

data.text: thanks for your reply!!! Which flexible solar panels would you recommend?
data.author: Julia Mir

data.text: without understanding your specific use case, Anker 21w 2 port or Anker 24w 3 port are probably the most consumer friendly options. If you arenâ€™t afraid of wiring Renogy makes some 100 watt & 150 watt flexible panels
data.author: Chris McCall

data.text: to be completely transparent I use a really large Anker Power Bank 20k mAh and charge when I can find an outlet. Anker makes larger Power Banks that can handle laptops but the are $180-$200 mine was $70
data.author: Chris McCall

data.text: Start riding, stop buying.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: i carry mine in the trailerâ€¦..
data.author: David O'Neill

data.text: WOW ðŸ˜³ðŸ˜³ðŸ˜³ is it worth carrying all this weight??? I remember once watching a film over bike travellers who went for a challenge competition from Paris to Tadjikistan on all kinds of solar powered electric bikes. They ALL had all kinds of technical issues on the way and most of them were forced to abandon the trip :( Those who managed to get to the final destination also had to deal with sophisticated repairs, ordering parts - delivery delays etc.... However the idea to explore wad of course very interesting and I'm sure the technology evolved a lot since that time!!! What's your reason for carrying so many panels?
data.author: Julia Mir

data.text:
my trailer holds up to 200 lbs. All of my power equipment,,,,, Trailer 400wh battery that inputs up to 130w from solar cells and outputs up to 300watts AC, enough power to recharge bike batteries, spare 500wh bike battery, all the solar cells you see in photo & related cables all weigh in at around 60 lbs. I get up to 50 miles a day propulsion from the sun. The spare solar cells in the photo i pull out for overcast skies and to maximize power near sunset. Mostly this equipment is very reliable. Three years ago i pulled this rig across the USA without the spare solar cells. The four here weigh less then 15 lbsâ€¦. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=bo1OXYqGwRI&list=PLAdOBRoqBbpssXBqKlxOfzAwSYRoVrVTS&fbclid=IwAR11jEAC2kSgzgNp66vpDCWVC7erb1xYOkvAQH-FIV0qFzWK9Q16VawYC64
David's Solar Journey Part 1

data.author: Law Cheung

data.text:
I put a cheap solar panel* on top of my rear pannier rack with cable ties and plugged it into a power bank in my rear pannier with great results. However most of my trips are weekends and long weekends and I don't need it. A Large power bank charged at home does the job. *This kind of panel: https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/384739768178
12V 40W Portable Solar Panel Kit MONO Caravan Home Camping USB Power Outdoor AU | eBay
